concern: So, I'm in highschool right now, and I want to learn some things (i.e linear algebra, maybe some other math courses). However, I can't really afford to pay for dual enrollment, and so, I figured I could just self-study or use MIT's Opencourseware for courses or something like that. But, I honestly don't want to take these courses again in college. Do most colleges require that I have to take for-credit courses or am I allowed to take a placement test or something? I also do competitive physics classes, and even though it's technically college level, it isn't for credit either; am I also able to take placement tests for that too?

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! I'm here to listen and support you. What's on your mind today?

I'm feeling anxious about my academic plans for college, particularly regarding courses I've already studied on my own. I'm wondering if there are ways to demonstrate my knowledge and avoid repeating them.

It sounds like you're eager to make the most of your college experience and avoid redundancy. That's a great initiative to have! Have you looked into options like placement tests or credit by exam at your college?

I've thought about placement tests and credit by exam as ways to demonstrate what I've learned on my own, but I'm still unsure about the specifics and how effective they might be for my situation. This uncertainty is adding to my anxiety about efficiently planning my college courses.

It's understandable that uncertainty about these options could contribute to your anxiety. But remember, you're taking a proactive approach, which is fantastic! Have you considered reaching out to an academic advisor at your college? They could provide more detailed information and help you navigate these options.

Yes, I've considered reaching out to an academic advisor to get clearer guidance on placement tests and credit options. I'm hoping this step will help ease my anxiety about making the most of my selfstudied courses in college.
That's a wise move! Academic advisors are there to help you succeed and make the most of your college experience. When do you plan to schedule an appointment with an advisor?

I plan to schedule an appointment with an academic advisor as soon as possible, ideally within the next week, to get the guidance I need. This step feels reassuring as I work through my concerns about optimizing my college path.

Scheduling an appointment with an advisor is a great step forward, and I'm glad to hear it's bringing you some reassurance. Remember, you're doing everything you can to make informed decisions about your college path.

I appreciate your encouragementit helps ease my worries about navigating my academic path. Even with these steps, I still feel a bit anxious about ensuring my selfacquired knowledge is properly recognized in college.
